name: Kepler-135
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-135 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-135 is a star with 1.6039999999999999 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.27 times its radius. It is located 2064.53 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-135 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-135 b

Kepler-135 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.07 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 6.00 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-135.

The mass of Kepler-135 b is 3.97 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-135 b is 1.81 that of Earth. At 3.97 Earth masses, Kepler-135 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-135 c

Kepler-135 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.10 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 11.45 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-135.

The mass of Kepler-135 c is 1.36 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-135 c is 1.16 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-135 c is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-135, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
